Guy Crockett stepped down as managing director in 1950, and Marvin Bower was elected in his place.{{RP|61}} McKinsey's profit-sharing, executive and planning committees were formed in 1951. The organization's client base expanded especially among governments, defense contractors, bluechip companies and military organizations in the post-[[World War II]] era. After seven years of consideration, McKinsey became a private corporation with shares owned exclusively by McKinsey employees in 1956.{{RP|12}} After Bower stepped down in 1967, the firm's revenues declined. New competitors like the [[Boston Consulting Group]] and [[Bain & Company]] created increased competition for McKinsey by marketing specific branded products, such as the Growth-Share Matrix, and by selling their industry expertise.{{cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/stories/2002-07-07/table-mckinsey-over-the-years|newspaper=BusinessWeek|date=July 7, 2002|title=Table: McKinsey Over the Years|accessdate=December 16, 2012}}{{cite news | last =Huey | first =John | title =How McKinsey Does It | newspaper =Fortune | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =November 1, 1993 | url =http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/fortune_archive/1993/11/01/78550/index.htm | accessdate =May 20, 2012 }} In 1971, McKinsey created the Commission on Firm Aims and Goals, which found that McKinsey had become too focused on geographic expansion and lacked adequate industry knowledge. The commission advised that McKinsey slow its growth and develop industry specialties.{{rp|14}}{{cite news|publisher=Harvard Business School|date=January 4, 2000|url=http://hbr.org/product/McKinsey---Co---Managing-/an/396357-PDF-ENG|accessdate=August 19, 2013|title=McKinsey & Company: Managing Knowledge and Learning|first=Christopher|last=Bartlett}} In 1976, [[Ron Daniel]] was elected managing director, serving until 1988.{{RP|42}} Daniel and Fred Gluck helped shift the firm away from its generalist approach by developing 15 specialized working groups within McKinsey called Centers of Competence and by developing practice areas called Strategy, Operations and Organization. Daniel also began McKinsey's knowledge management efforts in 1987.{{RP|15-17}} This led to the creation of an IT system that tracked McKinsey engagements, a process to centralize knowledge from each practice area and a resource directory of internal experts."{{RP|6-7}} By the end of his tenure in 1988 the firm was growing again and had opened new offices in Rome, Helsinki, São Paulo and Minneapolis.{{RP|15-17}} Fred Gluck served as McKinsey’s managing director from 1988 to 1994.{{cite news | newspaper =BusinessWeek | date =September 19, 1993 | title=The McKinsey Mystique | url =http://www.businessweek.com/stories/1993-09-19/the-mc-kinsey-mystique | accessdate =May 24, 2012 |first=John |last=Byrne }} The firm's revenues doubled during his tenure. He organized McKinsey into 72 "islands of activity" that were organized under seven sectors and seven functional areas.{{RP|18}} By 1997, McKinsey had grown eightfold over its size in 1977.{{cite news | last =Caulkin | first =Dimon | title =Management: The Firm that means McJobs for the Boys | newspaper =The Observer | location =Business Page | page =Page 6 | date =June 29, 1997 | url = | accessdate = }} In 1989 the firm tried to acquire talent in IT services through a $10 million purchase of the Information Consulting Group (ICG), but a culture clash caused 151 out of the 254 ICG staff members to leave by 1993. ===Recent history=== ====Further expansion==== In 1994, [[Rajat Gupta]] became the first non-American-born partner to be elected as the firm’s managing director.{{cite news | last =Sreenivasan | first =Sreenath | newspaper =BusinessToday | title=How did McKinsey's Rajat Gupta become the first India-born CEO of a $1.3 billion US transnational? | date =April 22, 1994 | url =http://sree.net/stories/bt-gupta.html | accessdate =May 20, 2012 }} By the end of his tenure, McKinsey had grown from 2,900 to 7,700 staff and 58 to 84 locations.{{cite news | last =Byrne | first =John | title =Inside McKinsey | newspaper =BusinessWeek | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =July 8, 2002 | url =http://www.businessweek.com/stories/2002-07-07/inside-mckinsey | accessdate = August 19, 2013}} He opened new international offices in cities such as [[Moscow]], [[Beijing]] and [[Bangkok]].{{RP|20}} Continuing the structure developed by prior directors, Gupta also created 16 industry groups charged with understanding specific markets and instituted a three-term limit for the managing director.{{RP|22}} McKinsey created practice areas for manufacturing and business technology in the late 1990s.{{RP|21, 23}} McKinsey set up "accelerators" in the 1990s, where the firm accepted [[stock]]-based reimbursement to help internet [[Startup company|startups]];{{cite news|last=Leonhardt|first=David|title=Big Consultants Woo Employees by Offering a Piece of the Action|work=The New York Times|page=1|date=October 22, 1999|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/10/22/business/big-consultants-woo-employees-by-offering-a-piece-of-the-action.html}} the company performed more than 1,000 e-commerce projects from 1998-2000 alone.{{RP|24}} The burst of the [[dot-com bubble]] led to a reduction in utilization rates of McKinsey's consultants from 64 to 52 percent. Though McKinsey avoided dismissing any personnel following the decline, the decline in revenues and losses from equity-based payments as stock lost value, together with a recession in 2001, meant the company had to reduce its prices, cut expenses and reduce hiring.{{RP|25}} In 2001, McKinsey launched several practices that focused on the public and social sector. It took on many public sector or non profit clients on a [[pro bono]] basis. By 2002 McKinsey had invested a $35.8 million budget on [[knowledge management]], up from $8.3 million in 1999.{{cite book | title =Vault Employer Profile: McKinsey & Company | publisher =Vault | year =2004 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=h5RZAAAAYAAJ&q=Vault+Employer+Profiles+-+Mckinsey+%26+Company&dq=Vault+Employer+Profiles+-+Mckinsey+%26+Company | accessdate =July 8, 2012 }}{{rp|1}} Its revenues were 50, 20, and 30 percent from strategy, operations, and technology consulting, respectively.{{RP|20}} In 2003 [[Ian Davis (businessman)|Ian Davis]], the head of the [[London]], UK office, was elected to the position of managing director.{{cite news | last =Thurm | first =Scott | title =McKinsey Partners Pick Barton to Lead Firm | newspaper =Wall Street Journal | publisher = | date =February 23, 2009 | url =https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB123536617936146431 | accessdate = May 24, 2012 }} Davis promised a return to the company’s core values, after a period in which the firm had expanded rapidly, which some McKinsey consultants felt was a departure from the company's heritage.{{cite news | last =Glater | first =Jonathan | title =British Manager Is Chosen To Lead Consulting Firm | newspaper =The New York Times | date =March 7, 2003 | accessdate =May 23, 2012 }} Also in 2003, the firm established a headquarters for the Asia-Pacific region in [[Shanghai]], China. By 2004, more than 60 percent of McKinsey's revenues were generated outside the U.S. The company started a Social Sector Office (SSO) in 2008, which is divided into three practices: Global Public Health, Economic Development and Opportunity Creation (EDHOC) and Philanthropy. McKinsey does much of its pro-bono work through the SSO, whereas a Business Technology Office (BTO), founded in 1997, provides consulting on technology strategy. By 2009, the firm consisted of 400 directors (senior partners), up from 151 in 1993.{{cite news | last =Stern | first =Stefan | title =McKinsey turns to its Asia chief Barton for top job | newspaper =Financial Times | date =February 23, 2009 | url =http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/1b6e4944-0149-11de-8f6e-000077b07658.html | accessdate = }} [[Dominic Barton]] was elected as Managing Director, a role he was re-elected for in 2012 and 2015. In February 2018, [[Kevin Sneader]] was elected as Managing Director. He will serve a three-year term beginning on July 1 2018.{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/a874cbc8-1a4a-11e8-aaca-4574d7dabfb6|title=McKinsey names Kevin Sneader new global managing partner|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} ====Galleon insider trading scandal==== {{See also|Raj Rajaratnam/Galleon Group, Anil Kumar, and Rajat Gupta insider trading cases|l1=Rajat Gupta and Anil Kumar}} Former McKinsey senior executives, [[Rajat Gupta]] and [[Anil Kumar]], were among those convicted in a [[Raj Rajaratnam/Galleon Group, Anil Kumar, and Rajat Gupta insider trading cases|government investigation]] into [[insider trading]] for sharing inside information with [[Galleon Group]] hedge fund owner [[Raj Rajaratnam]].{{cite news| url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2011/03/01/former-goldman-director-charged-with-insider-trading/ | work=The New York Times | first=Peter | last=Lattman | title=Ex-Goldman Director Accused of Passing Illegal Tips | date=March 1, 2011}}{{cite news| url=http://money.cnn.com/2009/10/22/news/companies/galleon_scandal_rules.fortune/index.htm | work=CNN | first1=Duff | last1=McDonald | title=Galleon scandal's executive conundrum | date=October 23, 2009}} Though McKinsey was not accused of any wrongdoing, the convictions were embarrassing for the firm, since it prides itself for integrity and client confidentiality.{{cite news | title =Rajat Gupta sues US regulator over Galleon case | newspaper =IBN Live | date =March 19, 2011 | url =http://ibnlive.in.com/news/rajat-gupta-sues-us-regulator-over-galleon-case/146446-7.html | accessdate =April 3, 2012 }} {{cite news | last =McCool | first =Grant | title =Money for inside information ended up in Bermuda, says Kumar | newspaper =The Royal Gazette | date =March 14, 2011 | url =http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20110314/BUSINESS02/703149977/-1/business | accessdate =April 3, 2012 }}{{cite news | last =McDonald | first =Duff | title =Galleon scandal's executive conundrum | newspaper =CNN Money | date =October 23, 2009 | url =http://money.cnn.com/2009/10/22/news/companies/galleon_scandal_rules.fortune/index.htm | accessdate =April 3, 2012 }} Following the initial allegations McKinsey no longer maintains a relationship with either senior partner,{{cite news|last=Rushe|first=Dominic|url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/support_services/article6945946.ece|title=McKinsey Jettisons Troubled Star Kumar|newspaper=The Sunday Times|date=December 6, 2009}}{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/30/us-galleon-rajaratnam-mckinsey-idUSTRE72T4GK20110330 | work=Reuters | title=McKinsey in uncomfortable Rajaratnam trial glare | date=March 30, 2011}} though the manner in which it severed ties attracted controversy.{{cite news|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/world/did-mckinsey-co-throw-rajat-gupta-under-the-bus-215594|title=Did McKinsey & Co throw Rajat Gupta under the bus?|publisher=NDTV.com|date=May 24, 2012|accessdate=July 18, 2013}} Senior partner Anil Kumar, described as Gupta's protégé,{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/06/01/goldman-gupta-idUSL1E8H1JP220120601 | work=Reuters | first=Grant | last=McCool | title=Protege testifies against McKinsey mentor Gupta | date=June 1, 2012}} left the firm after the allegations in 2009 and pleaded guilty in January 2010.{{cite news | last =Kouwe | first =Zachery | title =Guilty Plea in Galleon Insider Trading Case | newspaper =The New York Times | date =January 7, 2010 | url =https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2010/01/07/guilty-plea-in-galleon-insider-trading-case/ | accessdate =April 3, 2012 }}{{cite news | last =Savvas | first =Antony | title =McKinsey: Galleon tech insider trading is 'embarrassing' to our reputation | newspaper =Computerworld UK | date =July 12, 2011 | url =http://www.computerworlduk.com/news/it-business/3290894/mckinsey-galleon-tech-insider-trading-is-embarrassing-to-our-reputation/ | accessdate =April 3, 2012 }} While he and other partners had been pitching McKinsey's consulting services to the Galleon Group, Kumar and Rajaratnam reached a private consulting agreement, violating McKinsey's policies on confidentiality.{{cite news | last =Packer | first =George | title =A Dirty Business | newspaper =The New Yorker | date =June 27, 2011 | url =http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2011/06/27/110627fa_fact_packer | accessdate =April 3, 2012 }} Gupta was convicted in June 2012 of four counts of [[conspiracy (crime)|conspiracy]] and [[securities fraud]], and acquitted on two counts.{{cite news| url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2012/06/15/rajat-gupta-convicted-of-insider-trading | work=The New York Times | first1=Peter | last1=Lattman | first2=Azam | last2=Ahmed | title=Rajat Gupta Convicted of Insider Trading | date=June 15, 2012}} In October 2011, he was arrested by the [[FBI]] on criminal charges of sharing insider information from these confidential board meetings with Rajaratnam.{{cite news | last =Rothfeld | first =Michael |author2=Susan Pulliam | title =Gupta Surrenders to FBI | newspaper =The Wall Street Journal | date =October 25, 2011 | url =https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204777904576653850379354850 | accessdate =April 3, 2012 }}{{cite news | last =Hill | first =Andrew | title =Inside McKinsey | newspaper =Financial Times | date =November 25, 2011 | url =http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/2/0d506e0e-1583-11e1-b9b8-00144feabdc0.html#axzz1r2SIEwJk | accessdate =April 3, 2012 }} At least twice, Gupta used a McKinsey phone to call Rajaratnam and retained other perks — an office, assistant, and $6 million retirement salary that year{{cite news| url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303640104577440451784326274 | work=The Wall Street Journal | first1=Chad | last1=Bray | first2=Reed | last2=Albergotti | title=Charged Questions Barred | date=June 1, 2012}} — as a senior partner emeritus.{{cite news | last =McCool | first =Grant |author2=Dena Aubin | title =McKinsey in uncomfortable Rajaratnam trial glare | publisher =Reuters | date =March 30, 2011 | url =https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/30/us-galleon-rajaratnam-mckinsey-idUSTRE72T4GK20110330 | accessdate =May 2, 2012 }} After the scandal McKinsey instituted new policies and procedures to discourage future indiscretions from consultants,{{cite news|title=In Scandal’s Wake, McKinsey Seeks Culture Shift|first=Anita|last=Raghavanjan|date=January 11, 2014|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/12/business/self-help-at-mckinsey.html?_r=0|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=November 21, 2014}} including investigating other partners' ties to Gupta.{{cite news| url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2011-05-03/news/29499649_1_rajat-gupta-mckinsey-galleon | work=The Times Of India | title=McKinsey & Company scans Rajat Gupta's staff links | date=May 3, 2011}}{{cite news | last =Edgecliff-Johnson | first =Andrew | title =McKinsey concedes Galleon case 'embarrassing' | newspaper =Financial Times | date =July 10, 2011 | url =http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/23bf19d8-aae9-11e0-b4d8-00144feabdc0,Authorised=false.html?_i_location=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fcms%2Fs%2F0%2F23bf19d8-aae9-11e0-b4d8-00144feabdc0.html&_i_referer=#axzz1qcaGgvhT | accessdate =April 3, 2012 }} ==== Ongoing South African corruption scandal==== The [[Gupta family]] (no relation to Rajat Gupta) had strategically placed corrupted individuals in various South African government, utilities and infrastructure sectors. It is alleged that McKinsey was complicit in this corruption by using the Guptas to obtain consulting contracts from certain state-owned enterprises, including [[Eskom]] and [[Transnet]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/26/world/africa/mckinsey-south-africa-eskom.html?action=click&module=Trending&pgtype=Article®ion=Footer&contentCollection=Trending|title=How McKinsey Lost Its Way in South Africa|access-date=2018-06-27|language=en}} Working with Trillian Capital Partners (a consultancy which was owned by a Gupta associate),{{cite news|author=|title=Why McKinsey is under attack in South Africa|url=https://www.economist.com/news/business/21730191-consulting-firm-worked-trillian-capital-owned-gupta-family-associate-why-mckinsey|work=[[The Economist]]|date=12 October 2017}} they provided services to the value of R1 billion ($75 million) annually. Trillian was paid a commission for facilitating the business for McKinsey.{{Cite news|url=https://www.biznews.com/global-investing/2017/07/11/mckinsey-guptaleaks-south-africans/|title=South Africans urge US law-enforcers to bring Gupta and friends down with McKinsey - BizNews.com|date=2017-07-11|work=BizNews.com|access-date=2017-07-12|language=en-US}} McKinsey hired law firm [[Norton Rose Fulbright]] to carry out an internal investigation over the allegations. McKinsey's then Managing Partner, Dominic Barton issued a statement, following an internal investigation, in which the firm "admitted that it found violations of its professional standards but denied any acts of bribery, corruption, and payments to Trillian."{{Cite news|author=|title=Corruption Watch hits out at McKinsey|url=https://www.iol.co.za/business-report/companies/corruption-watch-hits-out-at-mckinsey-11601986/|work=[[Independent Online]]}} In September 2017, the [[Democratic Alliance (South Africa)|Democratic Alliance]], South Africa's main opposition political party, laid charges (Case Number: CAS 1156/9/2017) of fraud, racketeering and collusion against McKinsey in terms of Section 21 of the Prevention and Combatting of Corrupt Activities Act (Act 12 of 2004). The party alleged that McKinsey ignored red flags from senior South African staff members that deals between Trillian, [[Eskom]] and other Gupta-linked companies were not above board. The party said that McKinsey seems to have ignored these warnings as the profits were far too lucrative for McKinsey to pass up. {{cite web|author=|title=Mckinsey repayment does not let them off the hook|url=https://www.da.org.za/2018/07/mckinsey-repayment-does-not-let-them-off-the-hook|work=[[Democratic Alliance (South Africa)|Democratic Alliance]]}} [[Corruption Watch (South Africa)|Corruption Watch]], a South African non-governmental organisation, also filed a complaint about the controversial contract to the [[US Department of Justice]], alleging that there was a criminal conspiracy between McKinsey, Trillian and [[Eskom]] in contravention of US and South African law. {{cite news|author=|title=McKinsey & Company not off the hook|url=https://www.iol.co.za/business-report/companies/mckinsey-and-company-not-off-the-hook-15942722]]}} It was revealed in January 2018 that criminal complaints were filed against McKinsey & Company by the South African [[Companies and Intellectual Property Commission]]. South African prosecutors confirmed that they would enforce the seizing of assets from McKinsey.{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/da62b02a-fb94-11e7-a492-2c9be7f3120a|title=Subscribe to read|website=Financial Times}} South Africa's National Prosecuting Authority concluded in early 2018 that the payments to McKinsey and its local business partner, Trillian, were illegal, involving crimes such as fraud, theft, corruption and money laundering. McKinsey had subsequently been in discussion with Eskom and the National Prosecuting Authority’s Asset Forfeiture Unit to agree on a transparent, legally appropriate process for returning the R1-billion (US$74m) it had been paid - it was confirmed on 6 July 2018 that this had been concluded.{{cite news|author=|title=Pityana commends McKinsey for “paying back the money” - BUSA|url=http://www.politicsweb.co.za/politics/pityana-commends-mckinsey-for-paying-back-the-mone]]}} Eskom confirmed it received R99.5 million in interest from McKinsey on July 23, 2018. The interest payment covers the two years since McKinsey was paid almost R1-billion in 2016.{{cite news|author=|title=McKinsey pays back interest arising from Eskom contract|url=https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/companies/2018-09-06-mckinsey-pays-back-interest-arising-from-eskom-contract/]]}} The repayment of the near R1-billion illegal fee was not universally well received by South Africans. McKinsey continued to receive negative coverage in South Africa's business press with Sikonathi Mantshantsha, deputy editor of South Africa's [[Financial Mail]] magazine writing in an open letter to Mckinsey that "...I find it rich — too rich, in fact — for McKinsey to lecture anyone about the truth, principles and fairness. Let me tell you that the highest standards of ethics, truth and fairness begin with never taking that which does not belong to you in the first place. The second is to not pretend you are helping a client when you clearly are not. The third point is to acknowledge, however hard that may be, when you have done all and any of the above." This was in response to an unpublished email from Mckinsey which Mantshantsha described as making the "baseless and arrogant claim about there being no evidence presented to support the accusations of unethical conduct — possibly also thieving and corruption — that has financially crippled not only SA's electricity provider [[Eskom]], but also the rail and pipeline firm [[Transnet]]. And possibly others." Mantshantsha went on to say "as is now common cause, McKinsey has readily admitted that there is no legal basis on which to hold on to the funds."{{cite news|author=|title=An open letter to McKinsey: I find it rich — too rich, in fact — for McKinsey to lecture anyone about the truth, principles and fairness |url=https://www.businesslive.co.za/fm/opinion/between-the-chains/2018-07-26-sikonathi-mantshantsha-an-open-letter-to-mckinsey/]]}} Information relating to allegedly corrupt practices by McKinsey at [[Transnet]] in 2011 and 2012 came to light in late July 2018. The weekly [[Mail & Guardian]] newspaper reported that a "...new forensic treasury report shows how controversial former Transnet and Eskom chief financial officer Anoj Singh enjoyed overseas trips at the expense of international consulting firm McKinsey, which scored multi-billion rand contracts at the state owned entities." The "...report reiterates treasury’s recommendations that Singh’s conduct with regards to McKinsey should be referred to the elite crime-fighting unit, the Hawks, for investigations under the Prevention and Combating of Corrupt Activities Act (Precca). Under Precca, Singh would be investigated for allegations of corruption as the overseas trips alone constitute a form of gratification, which is illegal."{{cite news|author=|title=From Dubai to Russia ― how former Eskom and Transnet CFO Anoj Singh was bought|url=https://mg.co.za/article/2018-07-29-from-dubai-to-russia-how-the-former-eskom-and-transnet-cfo-was-bought]]}} The Sunday [[City Press (South Africa)|City Press]] reported that the forensic report in turn reported that "multinational advisory firm McKinsey paid for Singh to go on lavish international trips to Dubai, Russia, Germany and the UK, after which their contract with Transnet was massively extended."{{cite news|author=|title=Treasury drops looting bomb|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/treasury-drops-looting-bomb-20180729-4]]}}. Mckinsey issued a statement that the allegations were incorrect. Mckinsey stated that "based on an extensive review encompassing interviews, email records and expense documents, our understanding is that McKinsey did not pay for Mr. Singh’s airfare and hotel lodgings in connection with the CFO Forum and the meetings that took place around the CFO Forum in London and elsewhere in 2012 and 2013."{{cite news|author=|title=Right of Reply: McKinsey denies it paid for Anoj Singh’s lavish London junket|url=https://www.biznews.com/undictated/2018/08/03/right-reply-mckinsey-anoj-singh-cfo-junket]]}} In early August 2018 McKinsey admitted to helping [[Transnet]] Group Chief Executive Siyabonga Gama prepare a part of his thesis to obtain an MBA degree from TRIUM, a collaborative MBA programme jointly run by the [[NYU Stern School of Business]], the [[London School of Economics and Political Science]] and [[HEC School of Management]]. Several researchers at McKinsey’s Johannesburg office were assigned to help outline and prepare Gama’s submission to a joint thesis to which he had to contribute at least two chapters. Despite multiple earlier denials that any corrupt activities had been discovered, a McKinsey’s spokesperson said "... we believe this matter passed the threshold of reasonable suspicion that an offence may have occurred under South African law. As such, we reported it last year to relevant authorities under Section 34(1) of Precca."{{cite news|author=|title=McKinsey admits helping Transnet CEO with MBA, but Gama says only aid was editing|url=https://www.fin24.com/Companies/Industrial/exclusive-siyabonga-gama-on-mba-mckinsey-only-helped-with-language-and-flow-not-content-20180806]]}}. The TRIUM Global EMBA official twitter account was reported to have tweeted that "We have been made aware of recent allegations about academic integrity involving a TRIUM alumnus. TRIUM and its three Alliance Schools...take academic integrity issues very seriously."{{cite news|author=|title=MBA program investigating Transnet CEO's qualification|url=https://www.fin24.com/Companies/Industrial/mba-program-investigating-transnet-ceos-qualification-20180806]]}} ====2018 Lawsuit==== As of May 2018, the restructuring practice of the company is being sued by a competitor claiming knowingly misleading courts in order to land clients{{cite web|url=https://www.economist.com/business/2018/05/19/mckinsey-manages-to-get-itself-sued-for-racketeering|title=McKinsey manages to get itself sued for racketeering|website=economist.com}}. The company indeed disclose an average of only five potential conflicts per case, whereas other professional-services firms divulged, on average, 171 connections. In most cases it disclosed no conflicts at all.{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/mckinsey-is-big-in-bankruptcyand-highly-secretive-1524847720|title=McKinsey Is Big in Bankruptcy—and Highly Secretive|first1=Gretchen|last1=Morgenson|first2=Tom|last2=Corrigan|date=27 April 2018|publisher=|via=www.wsj.com}} === Role in Saudi clampdown on dissidents === In October 2018, in the wake of the Saudi dissident and journalist [[assassination of Jamal Khashoggi]], ''The New York Times'' reported that McKinsey had identified the most prominent Saudi dissidents on Twitter and that the Saudi government subsequently repressed the dissidents and their families. One of the dissidents was arrested. Another dissident's family members were arrested, and the cell phone of the dissident was hacked. McKinsey issued a statement, saying "We are horrified by the possibility, however remote, that [the report] could have been misused. We have seen no evidence to suggest that it was misused, but we are urgently investigating how and with whom the document was shared."{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/20/us/politics/saudi-image-campaign-twitter.html|title=Saudis’ Image Makers: A Troll Army and a Twitter Insider|access-date=2018-10-24|language=en}} Role in Trinidad and Tobago-Petrotrin Reports presented in the Trinidad and Tobago Parliament indicated McKinsey provided consulting recommendations to the amount of $66. Million dollars in total. The Petrotrin Refinery is set to close on November 30th 2018. (Reference TT Parliament Hansard). ==Organization== ===Structure=== [[File:McKinsey Office in Bucharest.jpg|thumb|upright|McKinsey office in [[Bucharest]], Romania]] McKinsey & Company was originally organized as a [[partnership]] before being legally restructured as a private corporation with shares owned by its partners in 1956.{{cite news | last =Bhide | first =Amar | title =Building the Professional Firm: McKinsey & Co.: 1939-1968 | newspaper = | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =March 1996 | url =https://books.google.com/books/about/Building_the_Professional_Firm.html?id=7ZkGHAAACAAJ | accessdate =April 10, 2012 }}{{cite book|author=Charles D. Ellis|title=What It Takes: Seven Secrets of Success from the World's Greatest Professional Firms|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rjlZ84yVOb4C&pg=PT116|date=January 25, 2013|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-1-118-56049-5|pages=116}} It mimics the structure of a partnership and employees are called "partners".{{cite book|first=Laura|last=Empson|title=Managing the Modern Law Firm : New Challenges, New Perspectives: New Challenges, New Perspectives|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QdTu86s-XBIC&pg=PA30|date=January 18, 2007|publisher=OUP Oxford|isbn=978-0-19-929674-3|pages=30}}{{cite news|last=Glater|first=Jonathan D.|title=British Manager Is Chosen To Lead Consulting Firm|work=The New York Times|page=2|date=March 7, 2003|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/03/07/business/british-manager-is-chosen-to-lead-consulting-firm.html}} The company has a flat hierarchy and each member is assigned a mentor.{{RP|65, 142}} Since the 1960s, McKinsey's Managing Director has been elected by a vote of senior directors to serve up to three, three-year terms or until reaching the mandatory retirement age of 60.{{cite book|author=Yeming Gong|title=Global Operations Strategy: Fundamentals and Practice|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GVFBAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA278|date=July 1, 2013|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=978-3-642-36708-3|pages=278}} The firm is also managed by a series of committees that each has its own area of responsibility.{{RP|22}}{{cite news|first=Dimon|last=Caulkin|title=Management: The Firm that means McJobs for the Boys|newspaper=The Observer|pp=Business Page, 6|date=June 29, 1997}} McKinsey has a de-centralized structure, whereby different offices operate similarly, but independently. Each office is expected to put the overall organization's best interest before the office's, which McKinsey refers to as the "one firm" principle. Consultants and engagements are often shared across offices.{{cite book | last =McDonald | first =Duff | title =The Firm: The Story of McKinsey and its Secret Influence on American Business | publisher =Simon & Schuster | date =September 10, 2013 | url =https://www.amazon.com/The-Firm-McKinsey-Influence-American/dp/1439190976 | doi = | isbn =1439190976 }}{{RP|11}} Revenues from all offices are pooled and an individual office's revenue does not directly affect it financially.{{cite book | last =O'Shea | first =James|author2=Charles Madigan | title =Dangerous Company | publisher =Random House | date =1997 | isbn =0-8129-2634-X }} The company's budgeting is centralized, but individual consultants are given a large degree of autonomy. McKinsey consultants are either industry experts, functional experts, or generalists that cover specific geographic regions.{{cite news |first=Dana |last=Milbank |date=October 12, 1993 |title=Critics Have Advice for McKinsey |newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]] |location=Toronto}} The firm has 23 industry practices focused on individual industries, nine functional practices that work in areas like finance, marketing or risk, and five Capabilities and Solutions areas related to technology consulting.{{cite book|author=WetFeet|title=Mckinsey and Company|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Hb9E1BzxDBUC&pg=PA10|year=2009|publisher=WETFEET, INC.|isbn=978-1-58207-872-4}}{{citation|url=http://www.mckinsey.com/client_service|title=Client Service|publisher=McKinsey & Company|accessdate=November 29, 2013}} ===Culture=== [[File:Marvin Bower.jpg|thumb|Marvin Bower, founder of modern-day McKinsey and its corporate culture]] [[Marvin Bower]] is credited with creating McKinsey's values and principles in 1937. He established a set of rules: that consultants should put the interests of clients before McKinsey's revenues, not discuss client affairs, tell the truth even if it means challenging the client's opinion, and only perform work that is both necessary and that McKinsey can do well. Bower created the firm's principle of only working with CEOs, which was later expanded to CEOs of subsidiaries and divisions. He also created McKinsey's principle of only working with clients the firm felt would follow its advice. Bower also established the firm's language. McKinsey calls itself "The Firm" and its employees "members". McKinsey says its consultants are not motivated by money. McKinsey & Company tries to keep a "very low profile public image".{{cite news|first=Martin|last=Birchall|title=Consultancy pioneer is still setting the pace|newspaper=The Times|pp=7|date=June 8, 2006|quote=It was also the first firm to hire MBA graduates from the top business schools to staff its projects, rather than relying on older industry personnel.}} The firm has a policy against discussing specific client situations. The firm says it does not advertise, though it did advertise allegedly for recruitment purposes in ''[[TIME Magazine]]'' in 1966. Members are not supposed to "sell" their services.{{cite news|first=Sandra|last=Laville|author2=Nils Pratley|title=Brothers who sit at Blair's right hand|newspaper=The Guardian|date=June 14, 2005}} McKinsey's consultants are expected to become a part of the community and recruit clients from church, charitable foundations, board positions and other community involvements. A 1993 profile story in ''[[Fortune Magazine]]'' said McKinsey & Company was "the most well-known, most secretive, most high-priced, most prestigious, most consistently successful, most envied, most trusted, most disliked management consulting firm on earth". According to ''[[BusinessWeek]]'' the firm is "ridiculed, reviled, or revered depending on one's perspective".{{cite news|title=The McKinsey Mystique|first=Tom|last=Rodenhauser|date=August 26, 2013|accessdate=June 20, 2014|url=http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2013-08-26/the-mckinsey-mystique|newspaper=BusinessWeek}} McKinsey's culture has often been compared to [[religion]], because of the influence, loyalty and zeal of its members. ''[[Fortune Magazine]]'' said partners talk to each other with "a sense of personal affection and admiration". An article in ''The News Observer'' said McKinsey's internal culture was "collegiate and ruthlessly competitive" and has been described as arrogant. The ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' said McKinsey is seen as "elite, loyal and secretive". According to [[Reuters]], it has a "button-down culture" focused on "playing by the rules".{{cite news|title=McKinsey shocked by insider-trading allegations|first=Steve|last=Eder|date=October 19, 2009|publisher=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2009/10/19/us-mckinsey-insider-trading-analysis-sb-idUSTRE59I5Y520091019|accessdate=December 2, 2013}} According to ''BusinessWeek'', some consultants say the firm has strayed from its original values as it increased in size. ''The Guardian'' said at McKinsey "hours are long, expectations high and failure not acceptable". ===Influence=== Many of McKinsey's alumni become CEOs of major corporations or hold important government positions. In doing so, they influence the other organization with McKinsey's values and culture. McKinsey's alumni have been appointed as CEOs or high-level executives at [[Google]], [[American Express]], [[Boeing]], [[IBM]], [[Westinghouse Electric]],{{cite news|first=James |last=Kim|title=McKinsey: CEO factory. Money|pp=1B|date=May 19, 1993|newspaper=USA Today}} [[Sears]], [[AT&T]], [[PepsiCo]], and [[Enron]].{{cite book | last =Rasial | first =Ethan|author2=Paul Friga | title =The McKinsey Mind | publisher =McGraw-Hill | date =2002 | isbn =0-07-137429-9 }} McKinsey alumni have held positions with [[Tony Blair]]'s office. [[Citicorp]] and [[Merrill Lynch]] have also hired many McKinsey alumni. As of 2008, McKinsey alumni held CEO positions with 16 corporations that have more than $2 billion in revenue. The firm was ranked by ''USA Today'' as the most likely company to work for and become a future CEO of a major corporation, with odds of 1 out of 690.{{cite news|first=Del|last=Jones|title=Some firms' fertile soil grows crop of future CEOs|newspaper=USA Today|date=January 1, 2008|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/money/companies/management/2008-01-08-ceo-companies_N.htm}} McKinsey's consulting work has also been influential in establishing many of the norms of how governments and corporations are run. The company has been influential in the British [[Department of Health (United Kingdom)|Department of Health]] for many years and was heavily involved in the discussions around the [[Health and Social Care Act 2012]].{{cite news|title=The firm that hijacked the NHS: MoS investigation reveals extraordinary extent of international management consultant's role in Lansley's health reforms |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2099940/NHS-health-reforms-Extent-McKinsey--Companys-role-Andrew-Lansleys-proposals.html#ixzz3IZP3vPi4|accessdate=November 9, 2014|publisher=Daily Mail|date=February 12, 2012}} === Critiques on culture === McKinsey’s culture has been under scrutiny after a number of scandals the firms was either directly involved in or indirectly associated with. The independent says that ‘McKinsey’s fingerprints can be found at the scene of some of the most spectacular corporate and financial debacles of recent decades',{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/analysis-and-features/mckinsey-how-does-it-always-get-away-with-it-9113484.html|title=McKinsey: How does it always get away with it?|date=7 February 2014|publisher=}} while Reuters names the scandalous incidents ‘not bad apples, [but] a culture of corruption’.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.reuters.com/felix-salmon/2011/03/09/mckinseys-corrupted-culture/|title=McKinsey’s corrupted culture|website=Reuters}} McKinsey is in some cases seen as complicit or emblematic for the culture in cases where they did not get prosecuted with criminal charges, or where their former employees engaged in illegal or morally unethical behavior. [[Enron]] was the creation of [[Jeff Skilling]], a proud McKinsey consultant of 21 years, who was jailed after the falldown. The Independent states that McKinsey had ‘fully endorsed the dubious accounting methods that caused the company to implode in 2001’, and that ‘the processes and principles he [Jeff Skilling red.] allowed were very McKinsey. The consultants used Enron as their sandbox.' {{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2002/mar/24/enron.theobserver|title=The firm that built the house of Enron|date=24 March 2002|website=the Guardian}} McKinsey does not disclose the nature of its relationship with Enron other than to confirm it was a client. The Guardian reported that Enron used McKinsey on 20 different projects. However, it must be noted that McKinsey has consistently denied to have given Enron advice on financing issues or that it had suspicions the company was using improper accounting methods. Nor has it been summoned before the Department of Justice to explain its role. Nevertheless, according to the Guardian, ‘Enronitis is virulent’. McKinsey is said to have played a significant role in the 2008 financial crisis by promoting the securitization of mortgage assets and encouraged the banks to fund their balance sheets with debt, driving up risk, which ‘poisoned the global financial system and precipitated the 2008 credit meltdown'.Ben Chu, McKinsey: How does it always get away with it? Independent, 7 February 2014 Furthermore, McKinsey advised [[Allstate]] Insurance to purposefully give low offers to claimants. The Huffington Post revealed that the strategy was to make claims "so expensive and so time-consuming that lawyers would start refusing to help clients."{{cite web|url=http://www.huffpostbrasil.com/entry/insurance-claim-delays-industry-profits-allstate-mckinsey-company_n_1139102|title=Insurance Industry Reaps Massive Profits From Delay|date=13 December 2011|publisher=}} Next to this, 2016 McKinsey partner Navdeep Arora was convicted for illegally depleting [[State Farm]] of over $500.000 over a period of 8 years, in collaboration with a State Farm employee.{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/ct-mckinsey-indictment-0106-biz-20160105-story.html|title=McKinsey and State Farm consultants bilked $900,000, feds say|first=Kim|last=Janssen|publisher=}} The most recent case of indirect involvement concerns [[Valeant]], a Canadian pharmaceutical company investigated by the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission|SEC]]. Valeant has been alleged of improper accounting, and that it used predatory price hikes to boost growth.{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2016/03/20/valeant-timeline-scandal/|title=What Caused Valeant's Epic 90% Plunge|publisher=}} The Financial Times states that ‘Valeant’s downfall is not exactly McKinsey’s fault but its fingerprints are everywhere.’{{Cite news |url=https://www.ft.com/content/0bb37fd2-ef63-11e5-aff5-19b4e253664a |title=McKinsey’s fingerprints are all over Valeant |last=Gapper |first=John |date=23 March 2016 |work=Financial Times |access-date=27 May 2018}} Three out of six senior executives were recent ex-McKinsey employees, as well as the chair of the ‘talent and compensation’ committee. Nevertheless, it must be kept in mind that McKinsey didn’t single-handedly cause the credit meltdown or the Enron scandal. The Independent says that McKinsey ‘just partly facilitated them, and blessed the actions of incompetent and greedy managements with their slick charts and beguiling jargon.' Furthermore, other defenders of McKinsey claim that the firm merely advises, and is not a decision-maker.{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2013/09/13/mckinseys-secret-influence-on-american-business.html|title=Want to be a CEO? Work here|first=Kerima|last=Greene|date=13 September 2013|publisher=}} ==Consulting services== McKinsey & Company provides [[management consulting]] services, such as providing advice on an acquisition, developing a plan to restructure a sales force, creating a new business strategy or providing advice on downsizing. Its consultants design and implement studies to evaluate management decisions using data and interviews to test [[hypotheses]]. Conclusions of the study are presented to senior management, typically in a [[PowerPoint]] presentation and a booklet. McKinsey & Company has traditionally charged approximately 25 percent more than competing firms with an average project of one million dollars. Prices were reduced in the economic slump following the dot-com bubble. According to ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', McKinsey clients estimate that the firm's advice turns out to be poor in retrospect about 10 to 20 percent of the time. A typical McKinsey engagement can last between two and twelve months and involves three to six McKinsey consultants. An engagement is usually managed by a generalist that covers the region the client's headquarters are located in and specialists that have either an industry or functional expertise. Unlike some competing consulting firms, McKinsey does not hold a policy against working for multiple competing companies (although individual consultants are barred from doing so). This has sometimes led to accusations of sharing confidential information or re-packaging a competitor's tactics as best practices. ===Environmental consulting=== [[Marginal abatement cost]] curves attempt to compare the financial costs of different options for reducing pollution in a region and are used in emissions trading, policy discussions and incentive programs.{{citation|url=http://www.homepages.ucl.ac.uk/~ucft347/Kesicki_MACC.pdf|first=Fabian|last=Kesicki|publisher=University College London Energy Institute|title=Marginal abatement cost curves for policy making|accessdate=December 10, 2012|date=November 2011}} McKinsey & Company released its first marginal abatement cost (MAC) curve for greenhouse gas emissions in February 2007, which was updated to version two in January 2009.{{citation|title=Greenhouse gas abatement cost curves|work=Sustainability and Resource Productivity|url=http://www.mckinsey.com/client_service/sustainability/latest_thinking/greenhouse_gas_abatement_cost_curves|publisher=McKinsey & Company|accessdate=December 16, 2012}}{{citation|author1=Jerker Rosander, Per-Anders Enkvist |author2=Tomas Nauclér |lastauthoramp=yes |date=February 2007|publisher=McKinsey & Company|url=http://www.mckinsey.com/Insights/Sustainability/A_cost_curve_for_greenhouse_gas_reduction|title=A cost curve for greenhouse gas reduction|accessdate=December 10, 2012}} McKinsey & Company's MAC curve has become the most widely used{{citation|quote=the most well known and widely used of which have been compiled by McKinsey and Company|publisher=University College London Energy Institute|date=April 2011|title=Marginal Abatement Cost Curves: A call for caution|accessdate=December 10, 2012|url=http://www.whoseolympics.org/bartlett/energy/news/documents/ei-news-290611-macc.pdf|author=[[Paul Ekins]], Fabian Kesicki, Andrew Z.P. Smith}} and is the basis for McKinsey’s consulting on climate change and sustainability.{{cite news|date=November 24, 2009|title=Green redemption|newspaper=The Economist|accessdate=December 10, 2012|url=http://www.economist.com/node/14952792|quote=McKinsey has become known as a climate-change consultant, thanks to its greenhouse gas "cost abatement curve". This clever little chart shows the relative opportunity costs of different abatement activities. McKinsey's curve and expertise on climate change have opened the doors and pockets of ministries and industries around the globe.}} McKinsey's curve predicts negative cost abatement strategies, which has been controversial among economists.{{citation|author1=Frank Ackerman |author2=Ramon Bueno |lastauthoramp=yes |publisher=Stockholm Environment Institute|title=Use of McKinsey abatement cost curves for climate economics modeling|date= January 25, 2011|accessdate=December 10, 2012|url=http://www.sei-international.org/mediamanager/documents/Publications/Climate/sei-workingpaperus-1102.pdf}} The [[International Association for Energy Economics]] said in ''The Energy Journal'' that McKinsey's cost-curve was popular among policymakers, because it suggests they can take "bold action towards improving energy efficiency without imposing costs on society."{{cite journal|journal=The Energy Journal|volume=32|issue=01|year=2011|issn=0195-6574|doi=10.5547/ISSN0195-6574-EJ-Vol32-SI1|title=The Policy Implications of Energy-Efficiency Cost Curves|first=Hillard|last=Huntington}} In a 2010 report, the Rainforest Foundation UK said McKinsey's cost curve methodology was misleading for policy decisions regarding the Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation (REDD) program. The report argued that McKinsey's calculations exclude certain implementation and governance costs, which makes it favor industrial uses of forests while discouraging subsistence projects.{{citation|title=McREDD How McKinsey ‘cost-curves’ are distorting REDD|url=http://www.rainforestfoundationuk.org/McREDD|publisher=The Rainforest Foundation|date=2010|first=Nathaniel|last=Dyer|first2=Simon|last2=Counsell|accessdate=December 16, 2012}} Greenpeace said the curve has allowed Indonesia and Guyana to win financial incentives from the [[United Nations]] by creating inflated estimates of current deforestation so they could demonstrate reductions in comparison.{{cite news|first=Alex|last=Morales|date=April 7, 2011|title=McKinsey Work Lets Congo, Guyana Get Aid, Cut Trees, Greenpeace Says|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|accessdate=December 10, 2012|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-04-06/mckinsey-work-lets-congo-guyana-get-aid-cut-trees-greenpeace-says.html}}{{cite news|publisher=The Huffington Post|first=Johann|last=Hari|title=Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation program (REDD)|date=July 7, 2011}} McKinsey said they had made it clear in the cost-curve publications that cost curves do not translate "mechanically" into policy implications and that policymakers should consider "many other factors" before introducing new laws.{{cite news|first=Gerard|last=Wynn|date=April 7, 2011|title=McKinsey defends its climate costs slide rule|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=December 10, 2012|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/04/07/us-climate-costs-idUSTRE7365KX20110407}} ==Recruiting and compensation== McKinsey & Company was the first management consultancy to hire recent graduates instead of experienced business managers, when it started doing so in 1953. Less than half of the firm's recruits are from business majors,{{RP|7}} while others have advanced degrees in science, medicine, engineering or law.{{cite book | last =Rasiel | first =Ethan | title =The McKinsey Way | publisher =McGraw-Hill | date =1999 | isbn =0-07-053448-9}}{{cite book|author1=Thomas J. Schaeper|author2=Kathleen Schaeper|title=Rhodes Scholars, Oxford, and the Creation of an American Elite|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AlM1V90kHQsC&pg=PA299|year=2004|publisher=Berghahn Books|isbn=978-1-57181-683-2|pages=299–}}{{cite news|url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/1999/10/18/1999_10_18_209_TNY_LIBRY_000019363|title=The World of Business: The Kids in the Conference Room|newspaper=The New Yorker|accessdate=July 18, 2013}} According to ''The Observer'', McKinsey recruits recent graduates and "imbues them with a religious conviction" in the firm, then culls through them with its "up-or-out" policy. The "up or out" policy, which was established in 1951, means that consultants that are not being promoted within the firm are asked to leave.{{rp|208}}{{cite news|title=Inside McKinsey|first=Andrew|last=Hill|newspaper=Financial Times|quote=Every two or three years, McKinsey determines whether its consultants will make progress to the next level in the firm. If not, it pushes them out|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/2/0d506e0e-1583-11e1-b9b8-00144feabdc0.html#axzz34Hf2CyZl}} About one-fifth of McKinsey's consultants depart under the up or out policy each year.{{cite news|last=Doward|first=Jamie|title=The firm that built the house of Enron|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2002/mar/24/enron.theobserver|accessdate=September 10, 2013|date=March 23, 2002}} McKinsey's practice of hiring recent graduates and the "up-or-out" philosophy, were originally based on Marvin Bower's experiences at the law firm [[Jones Day]] in the 1930s, as well as the "[[Cravath system]]" used at the law firm [[Cravath, Swaine & Moore|Cravath, Swaine and Moore]].{{rp|206}} There is an ongoing debate within the firm on how fast it should grow.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.hbr.org/cs/2011/03/the_tempting_of_rajat_gupta.html|title=The Tempting of Rajat Gupta|last=Kiechel|first=Walter|date=24 March 2011|publisher=Harvard Business Review Blog Network|accessdate=2 September 2011}} It said the work environment is demanding, involving extensive travel and long hours. ==Research and publishing== McKinsey & Company consultants regularly publish books, research and articles about business and management.{{RP|51}}{{RP|55}} The firm spends $50–$100 million a year on research.{{RP|54}} McKinsey was one of the first organizations to fund management research, when it founded the Foundation for Management Research in 1955.{{cite book|author=Elizabeth Haas Edersheim|title=McKinsey's Marvin Bower: Vision, Leadership, and the Creation of Management Consulting|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lBHPV2ZVKC4C&pg=PT28|accessdate=16 December 2012|date=13 December 2010|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-1-118-04014-0|pages=}} The firm began publishing a business magazine,''[[McKinsey Quarterly|The McKinsey Quarterly]]'', in 1964.{{cite book|author=Antonio Nieto-Rodriguez|title=The Focused Organization: Less Is More in Portfolio Management and Project Delivery|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=C8P4bM2XLzoC&pg=PA56|accessdate=December 16, 2012|date=May 1, 2012|publisher=Gower Publishing, Ltd.|isbn=978-1-4094-2566-3|pages=55}} It funds the McKinsey Global Institute, which studies global economic trends and was founded in 1990. Many consultants are contributors to the [[Harvard Business Review]].{{cite news|first=James|last=O’Shea|author2=Charles Madigan |title=The Firm’s Grip|newspaper=The Sunday Times|date=September 7, 1997}} McKinsey consultants published only two books from 1960-1980, then more than 50 from 1980 to 1996.{{RP|55}} McKinsey's publications and research give the firm a "quasi-academic" image.{{cite book|author1=John Micklethwait|author2=Adrian Wooldridge|title=The Witch Doctors: What the Management Gurus are Saying, why it Matters and how to Make Sense of it|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Lh1mPgAACAAJ|year=1997|publisher=Mandarin|isbn=978-0-7493-2670-8}} A McKinsey book, ''[[In Search of Excellence]]'', was published in 1982.{{cite book|title=Organizational Studies: Modes of management|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NdDt1MaJ42YC&pg=PA359|date=January 1, 2001|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=978-0-415-21554-1|pages=347–362|first=David|last=Guest}} It featured eight characteristics of successful businesses based on an analysis of 43 top performing companies.{{RP|87-89}}{{RP|348}} It marked the beginning of McKinsey's shift from accounting to "softer" aspects of management, like skills and culture.{{RP|359}} According to David Guest from [[King's College London|King's College]], ''In Search of Excellence'' became popular among business managers because it was easy to read, well-marketed and some of its core messages were valid. However, it was disliked by academics because of flaws in its methodology. Additionally, a 1984 analysis by ''BusinessWeek'' found that many of those companies identified as "excellent" in the book no longer met the criteria only two years later. A 1997 article and a book it published in 2001 on "The War for Talent"{{cite news|title=McKinsey’s Dirty War: Bogus 'War for Talent' Was Self-Serving (and Failed) Even a stacked deck couldn’t produce winners|first=Duff|last=McDonald|date=November 5, 2013|url=http://observer.com/2013/11/mckinseys-dirty-war-bogus-war-for-talent-was-self-serving-and-failed/|newspaper=The Observer|accessdate=July 3, 2014}} prompted academics and the business community to start focusing more on talent management.{{cite book|author1=Stephen Perkins|author2=Raisa Arvinen-Muondo|title=Organizational Behaviour: People, Process, Work and Human Resource Management|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XN6b0K0O7JEC&pg=PA162|date=3 January 2013|publisher=Kogan Page Publishers|isbn=978-0-7494-6361-8}}{{RP|163}} The authors found that the best-performing companies were "obsessed" with acquiring and managing the best talent.{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2002/07/22/020722fa_fact|title=The Talent Myth. Are smart people overrated?|last=Gladwell|first=Malcolm|date=22 July 2002|publisher=The New Yorker|accessdate=2 September 2011}} They advocated that companies rank employees by their performance and promote "stars", while targeting under-performers for improvement or layoffs.{{cite news | last =McDonald | first =Buff | newspaper =New York Magazine | location = | title=The Answer Men | date =July 26, 2009 | url =http://nymag.com/news/intelligencer/topic/58091/ | accessdate = April 10, 2012}} After the book was published, [[Enron]], a company which followed many of its principles, was involved in a [[Enron scandal|scandal that led to its bankruptcy]]. In May 2001, a Stanford professor wrote a paper critical of the "War on Talent" arguing that it prioritized individuals at the expense of the larger organization. McKinsey consultants published ''Creative Destruction'' in 2001.{{RP|247}} The book suggested that CEOs need to be willing to change or rebuild a company, rather than protect what they have created.{{cite news|title=Manager's Journal: The Welch Legacy: Creative Destruction|first=Richard|last=Foster|newspaper=Wall Street Journal}} It found that out of the first [[S&P 500]] list from 1957, only 74 were still in business by 1998.{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/630473|newspaper=The Economist|title=Core curriculum|date=May 22, 2001|accessdate=December 3, 2013|first=Chris|last=Zook|author2=James Allen }} The ''New York Times'' said it "makes a cogent argument that in times of rampant, uncertain change ... established companies are handcuffed by success."{{cite news|last=Andrews|first=Fred|title=BOOK VALUE; Even the Best Boats Need Rocking|work=The New York Times|page=7|date=22 April 2001|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/04/22/business/book-value-even-the-best-boats-need-rocking.html}} In 2009, McKinsey consultants published ''The Alchemy of Growth'', which established three "horizons" for growth: core enhancements, new growth platforms and options. {{cite book|author1=McGrath|author2=Ian MacMillan|title=Discovery-Driven Growth: A Breakthrough Process to Reduce Risk and Seize Opportunity|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z-N01KDot54C&pg=PA198|date=March 16, 2009|publisher=Harvard Business Review Press|isbn=978-1-4221-2949-4|pages=198}} In February 2011, McKinsey surveyed 1,300 US private-sector employers on their expected response to the [[Affordable Care Act]] (ACA).{{cite news|author1=Shubharn Singhal|author2=Jeris Stueland|author3=Drew Ungerman|publisher=McKinsey Quarterly|url=http://www.mckinseyquarterly.com/How_US_health_care_reform_will_affect_employee_benefits_2813|date=June 2011|accessdate=October 1, 2012|title=How US health care reform will affect employee benefits}}{{cite news|title=1 in 3 Employers Will Drop Health Benefits After ObamaCare Kicks In, Survey Finds|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2011/06/07/1-in-3-employers-will-drop-health-benefits-after-obamacare-fully-kicks-in/#ixzz2ALXc6tWM|date=June 7, 2011|accessdate=October 24, 2012|publisher=Fox News}} 30 percent of respondents said they anticipated they would probably or definitely stop offering [[Employer-sponsored health insurance#Employer-sponsored|employer sponsored health coverage]] after the ACA went into effect in 2014.{{cite news|publisher=Reuters|title=Many US Employers to Drop Health Benefits: McKinsey|date=June 7, 2011|accessdate=October 1, 2012|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/07/us-health-benefits-idUSTRE7564VR20110607}}{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Business/health-care-survey-finds-employers-stop-providing-plans/story?id=13801527#.UImuQIWWcYs|publisher=ABC News|title=Health Care Survey: Employers May Cut Plans After 2014| first=Alan|last=Farnham |date=June 9, 2011|accessdate=October 24, 2012}} These results, published in June 2011 in the McKinsey e-Quarterly, became "a useful tool for critics of the ACA and a deep annoyance for defenders of the law" according to an article in [[TIME Magazine]].{{cite news|first=Kate|last=Pickert|newspaper=TIME Magazine|date=June 20, 2011|accessdate=October 1, 2012|title=McKinsey Comes Clean About Its Controversial Insurance Study|url=http://swampland.time.com/2011/06/20/mckinsey-comes-clean-about-its-controversial-insurance-study/}} Supporters of healthcare reform argued the survey far surpassed estimates by the [[Congressional Budget Office]] and insisted that McKinsey disclose the survey's methodology.{{cite news|first=Milt|last=Freudenheim|date=June 20, 2011|accessdate=October 24, 2012|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/21/business/21insure.html?_r=3/|newspaper=The New York Times|title=Health Law in a Swirl of Forecasts}}{{cite news|first=Julian|last=Pecquet|publisher=The Hill|title=Baucus demands methodology behind healthcare reform study|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/healthwatch/politics-elections/166889-baucus-demands-answers-on-consultants-controversial-healthcare-reform-study-|date=May 16, 2011|accessdate=October 1, 2012}}{{cite news|first=Julie|last=Rovner|publisher=NPR|title=McKinsey Health Insurance Survey Raises Ruckus, Questions|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/health/2011/06/17/137254316/mckinsey-health-insurance-survey-raises-ruckus-questions|accessdate=October 1, 2012|date=June 17, 2011}}{{cite news|first=Rick|last=Ungar|publisher=Forbes (blog)|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/rickungar/2011/06/18/mckinseys-anti-obamacare-study-msits-just-business/|title=McKinsey's Anti-Obamacare Study May Be A Lie - But It's A Lie Worth Big Bucks To McKinsey|date=June 18, 2011|accessdate=October 1, 2012}} Two weeks after publishing the survey results, McKinsey released the contents of the survey including the questionnaire and 206-pages of survey data.{{cite news|first=Dwight|last=Schwab|title=After lengthy debt-ceiling crisis, Obamacare looms|date=July 28, 2011}} In its accompanying statement,{{cite news|publisher=McKinsey|title=Details regarding the survey methodology|date=June 20, 2011|accessdate=October 24, 2012|url=http://www.mckinsey.com/features/us_employer_healthcare_survey}} McKinsey said it was intended to capture the attitude of employers at a certain point in time, not make a prediction.{{cite news|first=Sam|last=Baker|publisher=The Hill|title=McKinsey stands by healthcare survey|date=June 20, 2011}}{{cite news|first=Marissa|last=Cevallos|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |title=McKinsey Releases Insurance-Survey Data; More Controversy Ensues|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/jun/20/news/la-heb-mckinsey-survey-healthcare-20110620|date=June 20, 2011}} Since 1990, McKinsey has been publishing ''[[Valuation: Measuring and Managing the Value of Companies]]'', a textbook on valuation.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Valuation-Measuring-Managing-Companies-Website/dp/111887370X|publisher=[[amazon.com]]|title = Valuation: Measuring and Managing the Value of Companies|accessdate=2015-08-05}}{{cite web|url=http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/886667.Valuation?from_search=true&search_version=service|publisher=[[goodreads.com]]|title=Valuation: Measuring and Managing the Value of Companies, 5th Edition Hardcover by McKinsey & Company |accessdate=2015-08-05}}{{cite web|url=http://eu.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-1118873734.html|publisher=[[wiley.com]]|title=Valuation: Measuring and Managing the Value of Companies, 6th Edition |accessdate=2015-08-05}} The book is now available in its sixth edition.{{cite web|url=http://www.mckinsey.com/client_service/corporate_finance/latest_thinking/valuation|publisher=[[mckinsey.com]]|title=Valuation: Measuring and Managing the Value of Companies, 6th Edition |accessdate=2015-08-05}} ==Consulting projects== According to ''The Firm'', McKinsey has been influential in establishing the norms of business, such as working in large-scale office settings. According to a 1993 profile in ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'' magazine, "while McKinsey has consulted for many of the current era's great successes... it has also been a fixture at many of the big losers." In ''The Firm'', author Duff McDonald said McKinsey helped restructure the [[White House]], guided corporations through large-scale re-organizations in post-war Europe and facilitated turn-arounds, but in other cases advised companies to adopt strategies that led to their collapse or was unable to prevent an impending bankruptcy. It said
McKinsey was a major player in the efficiency boom in the 1920s, the postwar gigantism of the 1940s, the rationalization of government and rise of marketing in the 1950s, the age of corporate influence in the 1960s, the restructuring of America and rise of strategy in the 1970s, the massive growth in information technology in the 1980s, the globalization of the 1990s, and the boom-bust-and-cleanup of the 2000s.
McKinsey & Company's founder, James O. McKinsey, introduced the concept of budget planning as a management framework in his fifth book ''Budgetary Control'' in 1922.{{cite book|author1=Barry Curnow|author2=Jonathan Reuvid|title=International Guide to Management Consultancy: Evolution Practice and Structure|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ctLTOJPZQIYC&pg=PA25|accessdate=December 16, 2012|date= December 3, 2005|publisher=Kogan Page Publishers|isbn=978-0-7494-4699-4|pages=25}}{{rp|25}}{{citation|last=Flesher|first=Dale|first2=Tonya|last2=Flesher|title=McKinsey, James O. (1889-1937)|work=History of Accounting: An International Encyclopedia|publisher=Garland Publishing|date=1996|pp=410–411|url=https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/40698463?uid=2&uid=4&sid=21104413282533}}{{rp|422}} The firm's first client was the treasurer of [[Armour & Company]], who, along with other early McKinsey clients, had read ''Budgetary Control''. In 1931 McKinsey created a methodology for analyzing a company called the General Survey Outline (GSO), which was established based on ideas introduced in the 1924 book ''Business Administration''. It was also known as the Banker's Survey, because McKinsey's clients who used it in the 1930s were predominantly banks.{{RP|22}} After the [[Wagner Act]] gave certain rights to employees to organize into unions in 1935, McKinsey started consulting corporations on employee relations. Later in the 1950s, the work of a McKinsey consultant on compensation was influential in "skyrocketing executive pay". It also helped many companies such as [[Heinz]], [[IBM]] and [[The Hoover Company|Hoover]] expand into Europe. In the 1940s, McKinsey helped many corporations convert into wartime production for World War II. It also helped organize NASA into an organization that relies heavily on contractors in 1958.{{cite book|author=Christopher D. McKenna|title=The World's Newest Profession: Management Consulting in the Twentieth Century|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9SJKYmkfvt8C&pg=PA82|year=2000|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-139-45553-4}}{{RP|105}} McKinsey created a report in 1953 for [[Dwight Eisenhower]] that was used to guide government appointments.{{cite news|title=The McKinsey Report|date=January 12, 1953|url=http://pdc-connection.ebscohost.com/c/articles/54170571/mckinsey-report|accessdate=July 3, 2014}} In 1973, McKinsey & Company led a project for a consortium of grocery chains represented by the U.S. Supermarket Ad Hoc Committee on a Uniform Grocery Product Code to create the barcode.{{cite book|author=IDG Enterprise|title=Computerworld|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KQMeZfQuVxoC&pg=PT42|date=31 May 1999|publisher=IDG Enterprise|pages=42|issn=0010-4841}}{{cite book|author1=James B. Ayers|author2=Mary Ann Odegaard|title=Retail Supply Chain Management|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FLTnul2yoKQC&pg=PA269|date=26 November 2007|publisher=Taylor &Francis|isbn=978-1-4200-1375-7|pages=269}} According to the book ''"Business Research Methods"'', the barcode became commonplace after a study by McKinsey persuaded [[Krogers]] to adopt it.{{cite book|author1=Donald Cooper|author2=Pamela Schindler|title=Business Research Methods: 12th Edition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AZ0cAAAAQBAJ|date=February 1, 2013|publisher=McGraw-Hill Higher Education|isbn=978-0-07-777443-1}} In the 1970s and 1980s, McKinsey helped European companies change their organizational structure to [[M-form]] (Multidivisional Form), which organizes the company into semi-autonomous divisions that function around a product, industry or customer, rather than a function or expertise.{{cite book|author1=Matthias Kipping|author2=Lars Engwall|title=Management Consulting : Emergence and Dynamics of a Knowledge Industry: Emergence and Dynamics of a Knowledge Industry|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ba_LE10UhagC&pg=PA191|date=June 20, 2002|publisher=OUP Oxford|isbn=978-0-19-158812-9|pages=191}}{{RP|208}}{{cite book|author=Harm G. Schröter|title=Americanization of the European Economy: A compact survey of American economic influence in Europe since the 1800s|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LpYWwI1yy9MC&pg=PA110|date=December 5, 2005|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-1-4020-2934-9|pages=110}}{{RP|110}} In the 1980s, AT&T reduced investments in cell towers due to McKinsey's prediction that there would only be 900,000 cell phone subscribers by 2000. According to ''The Firm'' this was "laughably off the mark" from the 109 million cellular subscribers by 2000. At the time cell phones were bulky and expensive. The firm helped the Dutch government facilitate a turnaround for [[Hoogovens]], the world's largest steel company as of 2013, through a $1 billion bankruptcy bailout. It also implemented a turnaround for the city of [[Glasgow]], which had problems with unemployment and crime. McKinsey created the corporate structure for [[NationsBank]], when it was still a small company known as [[North Carolina National Bank]]. McKinsey was hired by [[General Motors]] to do a large-scale re-organization to help it compete with Japanese auto-makers. The book ''The Firm'' said it was an "unmitigated disaster" because McKinsey focused on corporate structure, whereas GM needed to compete with Japanese automakers through manufacturing process improvement. A McKinsey consultant said GM did not follow their advice. A 2002 article in ''BusinessWeek'' said that a series of bankruptcies of McKinsey clients, such as [[Swissair]], [[Kmart]], and [[Global Crossing]], in the 1990s raised questions as to whether McKinsey was responsible or had a lapse in judgement. McKinsey recommended that Swissair avoid high operating costs in its home country by developing partnerships with airlines based in other regions. In order to attract partners, Swissair acquired more than $1 billion in shares of other airlines, many of which were failing. This led to huge losses for Swissair.{{cite news|title=A scary Swiss meltdown|date=July 19, 2001|url=http://www.economist.com/node/705265|newspaper=The Economist|accessdate=September 18, 2014}} Prior to the Enron scandal, McKinsey helped it shift from an oil and gas production company into an electric commodities trader, which led to significant growth in profits and revenues. According to ''The Independent'', there was "no suggestion that McKinsey was complicit in the subsequent scandal, [but] critics say the arrogance of Enron's leaders is emblematic of the McKinsey culture."{{cite news|first=Katherine|last=Griffiths|title=The Real Power Behind No 10; McKinsey is a Highly Secretive Consultancy Firm|newspaper=The Independent|date=June 27, 2005}} The government did not investigate McKinsey, who said they did not provide advice on Enron's accounting, but some questioned whether McKinsey knew about Enron's accounting problems{{cite news|last=Hwang|first=Suein|author2=Rachel Emma Silverman |title=McKinsey's Close Relationship With Enron Raises Question of Consultancy's Liability|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=January 17, 2002|url=http://faculty.msb.edu/bodurthj/teaching/ENRON/McKinsey%27s%20Close%20Relationship%20With%20Enron%20Raises%20Question%20of%20Consultancy%27s%20Liability.htm|accessdate=December 2, 2013}} or ignored warning signs. Former ''Financial Times'' journalist Duff McDonald said McKinsey's confidentiality policy often prevents the public from becoming informed about the firm's work, except after it is exposed through lawsuits or investigations. 13,000 McKinsey documents were released as part of a lawsuit against [[Allstate]], which showed that McKinsey recommended the company reduce payouts to insurance claimants by offering low settlements, delaying processing to wear out claimants through attrition, and fighting customers that protest in court. Allstate's profits doubled over ten years after adopting McKinsey's strategy, but it also led to lawsuits alleging they were cheating claimants out of legitimate insurance claims.{{cite news|last=Dietz|first=David|author2=Darrell Preston |date=August 3, 2007|title=Home Insurers' Secret Tactics Cheat Fire Victims, Hike Profits|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&refer=home&sid=aIOpZROwhvNI|accessdate=September 2, 2011}}{{cite news|last=Griffin|first=Drew|author2=Kathleen Johnston |date=February 9, 2007|title=Auto insurers play hardball in minor-crash claims|publisher=CNN|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2007-02-09/us/insurance.hardball_1_accident-victims-auto-insurers-allstate?_s=PM:US|accessdate=September 2, 2011}} ==Notable current and former employees== {{Main article|List of former employees of McKinsey & Company}} ==See also== {{portal|Companies}} *[[Big Three (management consultancies)|MBB - Big Three (management consultancies)]] ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons|McKinsey & Co.}} * {{Official website|http://www.mckinsey.com/}} * ''[http://www.mckinseyquarterly.com/ McKinsey Quarterly]'' {{Consulting}} {{Portalbar|Companies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mckinsey and Company}} [[Category:McKinsey & Company| ]] [[Category:Consulting firms established in 1926]] [[Category:History of Chicago]] [[Category:Life sciences industry]] [[Category:Outsourcing companies]] [[Category:Privately held companies based in Illinois]] [[Category:1926 establishments in Illinois]]

[[File:MeatDrawMonmouth040311.jpg|thumb|alt=A customer draws a ticket from the pot|A Meat draw underway]] [[File:MeatPrizes20110408.JPG|thumb|Meat prizes on display]] A '''meat raffle''' is a tradition of [[raffle|raffling]] off [[meat]], often in pubs and bars in Australia, in some areas of the USA, and in Western Canada. In most parts of Britain and Canada a meat raffle is known as a '''meat draw'''.<ref>{{cite web |website=Royal Torbay Yacht Club |title=Monthly Meat Draw|accessdate=18 June 2018|url=https://rtyc.org/monthly-meat-draw/}}</ref> In some cases the raffle is operated by a designated charity, though in Britain most of the proceeds are spent on prizes and the raffle is run as a social occasion and a method of enticing customers into a local pub. The meat ranges in animal and cut and often comes from local [[butchers]].
In the UK, a typical meat raffle would have approximately 25-30 tickets sold at £1 each, though there is considerable variation and some raffles are much larger. Depending on the specific raffle, when a winning number is called the winner can either pick their cut of meat or opt for a gift certificate. All proceeds typically go to a [[Charitable organization|charity]].
Also simply known as a '''meat tray''', the tradition is well known in Australian and New Zealand pubs. The trays of meat raffled vary in content: a barbecue style mix of steaks, lamb chops, sausages etc. is the most common, however "breakfast trays" (bacon, eggs, sausages) and "seafood trays" (prawns, oysters, mussels) are also common. Meat trays are usually raffled to raise money for local sporting teams, often those associated with the particular pub the raffle occurs in. The proceeds often help fund the team's end of season trip. Care must be taken with seafood trays given the propensity for the contents to spoil in the heat as the lucky winner continues drinking; often a friendly publican will store the tray in the fridge until the winner is sufficiently refreshed and ready to head home. {{Citation needed|date=March 2012}}
An Australian variant of the meat raffle is the [[chook raffle]], where a chicken is raffled off. A Canadian variant popular primarily in the [[Greater Sudbury|Sudbury]] area is "Porketta Bingo", in which a traditional Italian [[porchetta]] is given as a prize in a card game as a fundraiser for local [[minor hockey]] leagues.<ref name=sudbury>[https://www.thestar.com/living/food/article/1111711--sudbury-s-signature-dish-is-porketta "Sudbury’s signature dish is porketta"]. ''[[Toronto Star]]'', January 9, 2012.</ref>
Part of the interval at the [[BDO World Darts Championship]] includes a meat raffle to raise funds for youth teams.
The [[Dave (TV channel)|Dave]] TV comedy show ''[[Compete for the Meat]]'', hosted by [[Al Murray]], is loosely based on the concept of a meat raffle.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/02/05/magazine/05funny_humor.html?ex=1296795600&en=ab50405fe506dc86&ei=5090&partner=rssuserland&emc=rss Humorous NYTimes article] * [http://www.gcb.state.mn.us/ Meat Raffles & the Minnesota Gambling Control Board ] *[http://www.startribune.com/going-inside-the-juicy-world-of-minnesota-meat-raffles/295948691/ Star Tribune: Inside the juicy world of Minnesota meat raffles] *[http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-c1-minnesota-meat-raffle-20140911-story.html LA Times: On a Night Out, Minnesotans Hope to Get Lucky at Meat Raffle]
[[Category:Events in Minnesota]] [[Category:Events in Australia]] [[Category:Events in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Meat]] [[Category:Lotteries]] [[Category:Events in Canada]] [[Category:Canadian traditions]]
