{|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image= |Ship caption= }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship country= |Ship flag= |Ship name=''William Brown '' |Ship ordered= |Ship builder= |Ship laid down= |Ship launched= |Ship acquired= |Ship completed= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship reclassified= |Ship renamed= |Ship nickname= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship fate=Sank on 19 April 1841 |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class= |Ship tons burthen= |Ship length= |Ship beam= |Ship draught= |Ship depth= |Ship sail plan= |Ship complement= |Ship armament= |Ship notes= }} |}
'''''William Brown''''' was an American ship that sank in 1841, taking with her 31 passengers. A further 16 passengers were forced out of an overloaded [[Lifeboat (rescue)|lifeboat]] before the survivors were rescued. In the case of '''''United States v. Holmes''''', [[crewman]] Alexander Holmes was charged with [[murder]] and convicted of [[manslaughter]] for his actions.
==Sinking and rescue== Under the command of Captain George Harris, the ship departed from [[Liverpool]] on March 18, 1841 for [[Philadelphia]] with 17 seamen and 65 passengers, mostly poor Scottish and Irish emigrants. At about 10 p.m. on the night of April 19, ''William Brown'' struck an [[iceberg]] {{convert|250|mi|km}} southeast of [[Cape Race]], [[Colony of Newfoundland|Newfoundland]] and sank. The captain, eight seamen, and one passenger made it to the [[jolly boat]] (to be picked up six days later by a French fishing vessel), while nine crewmen and 32 passengers occupied the [[longboat]]. One person had died earlier on the voyage, and 31 passengers, many of them children, went down with the ship.<ref name=BCLC>{{cite web |url=https://law.resource.org/pub/us/case/reporter/F.Cas/0026.f.cas/0026.f.cas.0360.pdf |title=UNITED STATES v. HOLMES - Circuit Court, E. D. Pennsylvania. 26 F.Cas. 360 (1842) }</ref>
Before the two boats parted ways to increase their chances of being found, Captain Harris placed the [[first mate]], Francis Rhodes, in charge of the crowded, leaking longboat. At about 10 p.m., 24 hours after the sinking, the wind picked up, sending water over the longboat's [[gunwale]]s, and it began to rain heavily. The first mate shouted, "This . . . won't do. Help me, God. Men, go to work."<ref name=BCLC/> When the crewmen did nothing, he stated, "Men, you must go to work, or we shall all perish."<ref name=BCLC/><ref name=LL>{{cite web |url=http://law.jrank.org/pages/2482/Alexander-Holmes-Trial-1842.html |title=Alexander Holmes Trial: 1842 - Holmes Tried For Manslaughter |publisher=Law Library - American Law and Legal Information |accessdate=March 8, 2009}}</ref> Then, the seamen, among them Alexander Holmes, forced 12 men out of the boat. Two women also went into the frigid water, though they may have voluntarily followed their brother, Frank Askin. Early the next morning, two men were found to be hiding and were also jettisoned. All of the male passengers, except for two married men and a young boy, had been sacrificed,<ref name=BCLC/> while all of the crewmen remained aboard. Later that day, the survivors were picked up by the American ship ''Crescent'' and taken to [[Havre de Grâce]], [[Seine-Maritime]], France.<ref name=Times150541>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Dreadful Shipwreck |date=15 May 1841 |page_number=6 |issue=17671 |column=C }}</ref>
==Trial== When some of the passengers finally reached their destination of Philadelphia, they filed a complaint with the District Attorney. Holmes was the only crewman to be found in the city, so he was the only one charged. He was accused of murdering Frank Askin. A [[grand jury]] before Supreme Court Justice Henry Baldwin refused to [[Indictment|indict]] him on that charge, so it was reduced to manslaughter. In the case of ''United States v. Holmes'', the defendant was found guilty and sentenced to six months in jail and a $20 fine.<ref name=LL/> None of the other crewmen were ever brought to trial.
==Films== The 1937 film ''[[Souls at Sea]]'', with [[Gary Cooper]], [[George Raft]], and [[Henry Wilcoxon]], is somewhat based on the disaster, changing the cause of it to a fire accidentally set by a little girl. A story involving [[abolitionist]]s against the slave trade is involved, but the conclusion has Cooper's character forced to jettison passengers out of the overcrowded lifeboat, and facing a trial for murder as a result.
The 1957 film ''[[Seven Waves Away]]'' (renamed ''Abandon Ship!'' in the USA), was also loosely based on the incident, with [[Tyrone Power]] starring as "Alec Holmes".
A 1975 made-for-television version, ''The Last Survivors'', featured [[Martin Sheen]].
==See also== * ''[[R v Dudley and Stephens]]'', a British criminal case that cited ''United States v. Holmes''
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Deaths by drowning|!William Brown (ship)]] [[Category:Deaths due to shipwreck|!William Brown (ship)]] [[Category:Victorian-era merchant ships of the United States]] [[Category:Maritime incidents in April 1841]] [[Category:Shipwrecks in the Atlantic Ocean]] [[Category:Ship collisions with icebergs]] [[Category:Ships sunk in collisions]]

{{Infobox criminal | name = Yishai Schlissel | image_name = | image_size = | image_caption = |birth_date = 10 December 1975 | birth_place = [[Yad Binyamin]], [[Israel]] | residence = [[Modi'in Illit]], [[West Bank]] | nationality = Israeli | religion = [[Haredi Judaism]] | conviction = stabbed marchers during the Jerusalem gay pride parade in 2005
stabbed teenage girl to death and wounded others during the Jerusalem gay parade in 2015 | conviction_penalty = 12 years in prison
Payment of compensation in the amount of 280 000 NIS for the three victims
Life plus 31 years in prison
Payment of compensation in the amount of 2 064 000 NIS | conviction_status = | alias = | children = 4 | motive = Religious convictions | occupation = | spouse = | parents = }} '''Yishai Schlissel''' (also spelled '''Shlisel'''; {{lang-he-n|ישי שליסל}}; born 10 December 1975) is an [[Israel]]i convicted criminal. He stabbed marchers during the [[Jerusalem gay pride parade]] in 2005, for which he served ten years in prison. On 30 July 2015, during the 2015 Jerusalem gay pride, he stabbed 16-year-old Shira Banki to death, and wounded six other people. The incident occurred just three weeks after his release from prison. On 24 August, Schlissel was indicted for murder, six counts of attempted murder, and wounding under aggravating circumstances,[http://www.haaretz.co.il/1.2714458’], ''An indictment for murder against Yishai Schlissel'', Haaretz, August 24, 2015 (Hebrew) and detained until the end of proceedings. On June 26 2016, he was sentenced to life plus 31 years in prison, as well as pay NIS 2,064,000 (around $650,000) in damages. [http://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Life-sentence-for-Jerusalem-pride-parade-stabber-who-killed-teen-girl-457749], ''Life sentence for Jerusalem pride parade stabber who killed teen girl'', The Jerusalem Post, June 26, 2016 ==Early life== Schlissel was born on 10 December 1975 in [[Yad Binyamin]].[http://www.timesofisrael.com/pm-visits-pride-attack-victim-defends-right-to-live-in-peace/ PM visits pride attack victim, defends ‘right to live in peace’], ''The Times of Israel'', July 31, 2015[http://www.bhol.co.il/Article.aspx?id=87722מוזר ומופנם, או איש עקרונות קנאי - מי אתה ישי שליסל?], July 31, 2015 He was the eldest of ten children. His parents are the children of [[The Holocaust|Holocaust]] survivors. He studied [[Talmud]], and is very religious. He later studied in a [[kolel]] in Jerusalem. ==Criminal acts and convictions== In 2005, Schlissel stabbed three marchers during the gay pride parade in [[Jerusalem]]. As a result, he was convicted of [[attempted murder]] and [[aggravated assault]], and sentenced to twelve years in prison. In 2007, his sentence was reduced to ten years on appeal. Schlissel served his sentence at [[Maasiyahu Prison]]. In 2008, he was hospitalized for a month and a half over mental health issues and diagnosed with a paranoid psychiatric condition.http://10tv.nana10.co.il/Article/?ArticleID=1141498 Schlissel was released in June 2015.{{cite news|title=6 stabbed at Jerusalem Gay Pride Parade by ultra-Orthodox Jewish assailant|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/israel/1.668796|publisher=Haaretz|date=July 30, 2015}}https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/.premium-1.668832 Shortly after his release, he distributed a homophobic letter in his hometown which read, "It is the obligation of every Jew to keep his soul from punishment and stop this giant desecration of God's name next Thursday."Joe Williams, [http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2015/08/02/victim-of-jerusalem-pride-attack-dies-of-injuries/ Victim of Jerusalem Pride attack dies of injuries], ''[[PinkNews]]'', August 2, 2015 He was not tracked by the Judea and Samaria Police District because his previous crime had occurred in Jerusalem, outside of their jurisdiction. Moreover, [[Moshe Edry]], the chief of the Jerusalem District Police, was not warned that Schlissel would be coming to Jerusalem. On 30 July 2015, only three weeks after being released, he stabbed six marchers during the [[Jerusalem gay pride parade]]. The act was widely condemned,{{cite news|title=Yishai Schlissel: 5 Fast Facts You Need to Know|url=http://heavy.com/news/2015/07/yishai-schlissel-jerusalem-gay-pride-stabbing-2005-attack-release/|publisher=Heavy.com|date=July 10, 2015}} including by Prime Minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu]].Stuart Winer, [http://www.timesofisrael.com/netanyahu-slams-gay-pride-attack-we-will-bring-those-responsible-to-justice/ After attack on pride parade, PM condemns ‘despicable hate crime’], ''The Times of Israel'', July 30, 2015 One of the victims, 16-year-old Shira Banki, died of her wounds at the [[Hadassah Medical Center]] three days later, on 2 August 2015.{{cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/israel/1.669161|date=August 2, 2015|accessdate=August 2, 2015|first=Yaniv|last=Kubovich|newspaper=Haaretz|title=16-year-old stabbed in Jerusalem pride parade succumbs to wounds}} Shortly after, Prime Minister Netanyahu offered his condolences, adding "We will deal with the murderer to the fullest extent of the law." A psychiatric evaluation by the [[Israel Prison Service]], with which Schlissel refused to cooperate, found him fit to stand trial. However, after state psychiatrists argued that his refusal to cooperate rendered the evaluation inconclusive, the court ordered that he be hospitalized for a 48-hour observation period for reevaluation. He was again found fit to stand trial.https://www.timesofisrael.com/gay-parade-stabber-deemed-fit-to-stand-trial/ On 24 August 2015, Shlissel was charged with one count of murder and six counts of attempted murder and aggravated assault at the Jerusalem District Court.http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4693866,00.html He refused to recognize the authority of the court to try him due to it not abiding by Jewish religious law.https://www.timesofisrael.com/pride-parade-stabber-to-undergo-further-psychiatric-evaluation/ He announced that he would refuse to be represented by an attorney, and did not cooperate with the public defender assigned to represent him. On April 19, 2016, he was convicted.{{cite news|title=Jerusalem gay pride parade stabber convicted of murder|url=http://www.jta.org/2016/04/19/news-opinion/israel-middle-east/jerusalem-gay-pride-parade-stabber-convicted-of-murder|accessdate=April 20, 2016|work=Jewish Telegraphic Agency|date=April 19, 2016}} On June 26, 2016, he was sentenced to life plus 31 years in prison, and was ordered to pay [[New Israeli shekel|NIS]] 2,064,000 in compensation to the families of his victims. Schlissel is serving his sentence in [[Ayalon Prison]]. In August 2016, Schlissel tore up pictures of another inmate's daughters due to them being "immodestly dressed", and was subsequently beaten by the inmate until guards separated them. Schlissel was hospitalized as a result of the beating he sustained, and was temporarily placed in solitary confinement as a disciplinary measure. After prison authorities carried out an evaluation, it was decided to separate him from other inmates due to his volatile behavior, and he was given his own cell in a protected area of the prison. One month later, Schlissel was again attacked and had to be hospitalized after an argument between him and two convicted mobsters in the prison yard escalated to the mobsters beating him until guards intervened.https://www.timesofisrael.com/gay-pride-killer-beaten-up-in-prison-in-argument-over-his-crime/https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4842863,00.html ==Personal life== Before his prison sentence, Schlissel resided in [[Modi'in Illit]], a [[Haredi Judaism|Haredi]] [[Israeli settlement]] and city in the [[West Bank]].Chaim Levinson, Yaniv Kubovich, [http://www.haaretz.com/news/israel/.premium-1.668832 Israel Police to probe failure to monitor Jerusalem gay pride parade assailant], ''Haaretz'', July 31, 2015 He is an Israeli [[ultra-Orthodox Judaism|ultra-Orthodox Jew]].[http://www.timesofisrael.com/six-stabbed-at-jerusalem-pride-parade-by-same-assailant-who-attacked-parade-in-2005/ Six stabbed at Jerusalem pride parade by same assailant who attacked parade in 2005], ''The Times of Israel'', July 30, 2015[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-33726634 Jerusalem Gay Pride: Six stabbed 'by ultra-Orthodox Jew'], ''BBC News'', July 30, 2015 Prior to his crime, he was married, with four children. He divorced his wife at the beginning of his imprisonment in 2005. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Schlissel, Yishai}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from the West Bank]] [[Category:Israeli Orthodox Jews]] [[Category:Violence against LGBT people]] [[Category:Israeli criminals]] [[Category:Israeli people convicted of murder]] [[Category:21st-century criminals]] [[Category:1975 births]] [[Category:Murder in Israel]] [[Category:Murder in 2015]] [[Category:Terrorist incidents in Israel in 2015]]
